title: The red dot in the image above represents the anchor point. Notice how the scaling is done in relation to the anchor point. That is, everything is either stretched toward or away from the anchor point.

title: A Note about Anchor Point and Position

inline_content.Text: A Note about Anchor Point and Position

title: We did all our transforms above without changing the anchor point. Sometimes it is necessary to change it, though, like if you want to rotate around some other point besides the center. However, this can be a little tricky.

inline_content.Text: We did all our transforms above without changing the anchor point. Sometimes it is necessary to change it, though, like if you want to rotate around some other point besides the center. However, this can be a little tricky.

title: The anchor point and position are both at the same place. The anchor point is expressed as a unit of the layerâ€™s coordinate system (default is
c
) and the position is expressed in the superlayerâ€™s coordinate system. They can be set like this

inline_content.Text: The anchor point and position are both at the same place. The anchor point is expressed as a unit of the layerâ€™s coordinate system (default is
) and the position is expressed in the superlayerâ€™s coordinate system. They can be set like this

title:
myLayer.anchorPoint = CGPoint(x: 0.0, y: 1.0)
myLayer.position = CGPoint(x: 50, y: 50)

content_resolved.code:
myLayer.anchorPoint = CGPoint(x: 0.0, y: 1.0)
myLayer.position = CGPoint(x: 50, y: 50)

title: If you only set the anchor point without changing the position, then the frame changes so that the position will be in the right spot. Or more precisely, the frame is recalculated based on the new anchor point and old position. This usually gives unexpected results. The following two articles have an excellent discussion of this.

inline_content.Text: If you only set the anchor point without changing the position, then the frame changes so that the position will be in the right spot. Or more precisely, the frame is recalculated based on the new anchor point and old position. This usually gives unexpected results. The following two articles have an excellent discussion of this.
